comment.author: 39967544@N00
comment._content: In actual fact this is a photo of the AUSN Company's passenger liner Indarra, built in 1912 and sold in 1920 for further service. From 1923 until her destruction during World War 2 she was the Japanese Horai Maru.

comment.author: 28834987@N00
comment._content: This is definitely the SS Indarra. My Grandfather was an officer on this ship during WW1. It was used as a troop ship in 1918 bringing soldiers and nurses back from the European War. My grandmother was a nurse returning from the war and met my grandfather on the Indarra. They bought the engagement ring in south africa on the way home. I have a beautiful photograph of the ship in our loungeroom, which hung in my grandparents house. my grandfather's name was Ralph Pattison.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content:
thanks to both of you for your information, we've updated our records accordingly.  
Georgia, Registration
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 64570676@N08
comment._content: My great grandfather was a sailor on this ship during WW1. I have a diary he wrote about the ship, its adventures and the movements of the convoy during its time in the Med. It makes for a interesting read.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/64570676@N08] How fascinating & fantastic that you still have the diary :)
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
